prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
In silence I must first learn to hear your voice,
Through cacophony of doubt and fear that brew,
Making stillness not a luxury but a choice.

Truth demands patience, a willingness to wait,
For its whisper often comes when noise subsides,
Not in thunderous certainty or debate,
But in gentle revelations where wisdom hides.

How can I claim to speak what I cannot hear?
How can I offer others what I refuse?
Truth requires that first I draw you near,
Before your sacred power I dare to use.

So I shall listen deeply, with open heart,
Only then may truth and I no longer part.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender heart and soul,
The vastness of eternity
Could not contain what makes me whole.

Your touch, a whisper on my skin,
Your voice, a melody divine,
Each moment that I've ever been
Was meant to make your spirit mine.

The stars may falter in their course,
The oceans drain of every drop,
Yet still my love with endless force
Would flow for you and never stop.

For nothing less than all you are
Could satisfy this yearning heart,
You are my compass, north and star,
My end, beginning, every part.

Not as distant specks of ancient light,

Not as an emptiness to be filled,

When I finally spoke my truth.

For the first time in my life, I am awake.

Their flags and their banners they are waving,
With joy and excitement they shout,
A sea of colors dancing in sunlight,
As dreams and hopes flutter about.

United in purpose and passion,

Their flags and their banners keep waving,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you,
While distant bombs fall out of view.
We laugh at headlines, scroll away,
Forgetting lives lost yesterday.

In cushioned rooms we theorize,
About the conflicts we despise,
Yet never feel the searing heat,
Of homes ablaze on some far street.

War's a joke until it's not,
Until it's at your doorstep fought,
Until the hunger gnaws your child,
Until your homeland's been defiled.

So laugh we might at powers that be,
Who play their games across the sea,
But somewhere tears fall just as true,
For war's no joke—except to me and you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I have not seen
As others saw—I could not bring
My passions from a common spring.

From the same source I have not taken
My sorrow; I could not awaken
My heart to joy at the same tone;
And all I loved, I loved alone.

Then—in my childhood, in the dawn
Of a most stormy life—was drawn
From every depth of good and ill
The mystery which binds me still:

From the torrent, or the fountain,
From the red cliff of the mountain,
From the sun that 'round me rolled
In its autumn tint of gold,

From the lightning in the sky
As it passed me flying by,
From the thunder and the storm,
And the cloud that took the form
When the rest of Heaven was blue
Of a demon in my view.

From the same source I have not taken
My sorrow; I could not awaken

From every depth of good and ill
The mystery which binds me still:

From the torrent, or the fountain,
From the red cliff of the mountain,
From the sun that 'round me rolled
In its autumn tint of gold,

From the lightning in the sky
As it passed me flying by,
From the thunder and the storm,
And the cloud that took the form
When the rest of Heaven was blue
Of a demon in my view.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like evening stars,
Appearing one by one until
The sky is thick with anxious light.

They follow me through waking hours,
And chase me down in restless sleep,
Each worry growing teeth and claws
To tear at hope's embattled keep.

My fears of failure, loss, and pain,
Of loneliness and time's swift flight,
Of words unsaid and love unshown,
Of darkness overwhelming light.

Yet even as they crowd around,
A whisper cuts through their demands:
That courage isn't fearlessness,
But moving forward, trembling hands.

My God, how many are my fears!
But greater still your presence here,
As dawn dissolves the starry host,
And faith outshines what I revere.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

Wild and unblinking, depths of flame,
Where reason drowns and shadows rise,
A gaze that puts the stars to shame.

His pupils, black as midnight wells,
Hold visions only he can see.
Each glance a story that he tells
Of worlds that twist reality.

I stand transfixed, unable to flee
This burning stare that peels my skin,
Exposing truths I fear to see,
The chaos churning deep within.

What demons dance behind that gaze?
What fever burns inside his mind?
I'm lost within this haunted maze,
Two souls, by madness intertwined.

Heights make hearts race, spiders cause screams,
Failure haunts waking hours, rejection fills dreams.

For in our fears, we are never alone,
They're seeds of strength that have quietly grown.
Everyone has a fear—this makes us human, true,
The courage comes in what we choose to do.

Fire up the Sky

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Watch them dance in midnight dark,
Crimson, gold, and silver bright,
Painting dreams across the night.

They climb and soar on plumes of flame,
Each explosion calls your name,
Fleeting stars of human make,
Leaving trails in their wake.

Children gasp with wide-eyed wonder,
As the heavens split asunder,
With bursting blooms of light divine,
Where cosmic fire and earth combine.

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Ignite the soul, imprint the heart,
With memories of summer nights,
Illuminated by these fleeting lights.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge when storms rage wild,
My shelter when I feel undone,
My comfort as thy child.

In morning light, I seek thy face,
In darkness, feel thy hand.
Thy presence fills each empty space
Where doubts like shadows stand.

When desert paths stretch endlessly,
My soul thirsts deep for thee.
No earthly spring could satisfy
The longing thou hast placed in me.

Thy glory shines beyond the stars,
Yet dwells within my heart.
No distance keeps, no barrier bars
Thy love—my counterpart.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
All others fade like mist.
In thee I find my cornerstone,
In thee, my soul exists.

O God! Thou art my God alone.

And love's enduring grace.

When we danced beneath stars that knew our names,
When promises were etched in constellations
And time moved slower than cosmic dust.

It seems like light years ago
That your laughter echoed through galaxies,
When your touch was as certain as gravity
And our orbits perfectly aligned.

It seems like light years ago
When we were supernovas of possibility,
Burning bright with dreams unmeasured,
Our futures stretching endless as space.

Now across this vast expanse of memory,
I reach through the darkness between us,
Knowing that light from dead stars
Still travels toward eyes that once saw them.

It seems like light years ago—
Yet somehow, the distance grows,
While paradoxically, you remain
As close as the light in my bones.

Where once a river proudly flowed,
Mirrors for the sky's domain,
Keepers of secrets never told.

Parched earth cracks and yearns for rain,
As memory of abundance fades.

When drought's long sentence is delayed?

Small creatures gather at the edge,
Their thirst a common prayer shared.
Life clings to this liquid pledge,
This promise water has declared.

In these pools, though small and few,
The world still finds its way to shine—
Reflecting back the endless blue,
Holding fast to hope divine.

# Morning Departure

You can hear the excitement start to linger
As the early morning train departs.
Steel wheels whisper promises of elsewhere,
A symphony of new beginnings.

Windows frame sleepy towns in passing,
Dawn paints the sky in watercolor hues.
Strangers share knowing glances,
Each carrying stories yet to unfold.

The rhythm of the rails keeps time
With heartbeats quickened by possibility.
Distance grows between what was
And what might be waiting down the line.

Landscapes blur into memory,
As anticipation builds with every mile.
You can feel the world expanding
With each breath of morning air.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the Highways of Woes

Asphalt stretches like dark ribbons of fate,
Where travelers bear burdens, small and great.
At the highways of woes, we journey alone,
Each mile marked by sighs and silent groans.

Headlights pierce through fog of doubt and fear,
Illuminating paths that never seem clear.
Roadside markers of dreams left behind,
And exit signs to futures undefined.

Some speed through valleys of shadow and pain,
Others stall, caught in sorrow's heavy rain.
Broken white lines like memories fade,
On this endless road that time has made.

Yet even on these highways of despair,
Dawn breaks golden on those who dare
To keep moving forward, despite the toll,
For every road, even this one, has a soul.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
God is the refuge of his saints,
When storms of sharp distress invade;
Ere we can offer our complaints,
Behold Him present with His aid.

Let mountains from their seats be hurled
Down to the deep, and buried there,
Convulsions shake the solid world—
Our faith shall never yield to fear.

Loud may the troubled ocean roar;
In sacred peace our souls abide;
While every nation, every shore,
Trembles and dreads the swelling tide.

There is a stream whose gentle flow
Supplies the city of our God,
Life, love, and joy, still gliding through,
And watering our divine abode.

That sacred stream, Thine holy word,
Our grief allays, our fear controls;
Sweet peace Thy promises afford,
And give new strength to fainting souls.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into shadows, unseen.
A whisper of breath, a heartbeat denied,
As she slips between cracks of what has been.

The world grows too loud with its constant demands,
Its eyes ever watching, its judgment severe.
She seeks the soft silence that no one understands,
Where thoughts can roam freely without any fear.

In corners of quiet, in darkness complete,
She gathers her strength like stars gather night.
This vanishing act—not retreat, but retreat—
A necessary pause before stepping to light.

For hiding's not weakness but wisdom sometimes,
A shelter where broken things learn to mend.
In stillness she hears her own soul's gentle chimes,
And emerges, at last, whole again in the end.

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For in the garden of humanity, we're different seeds.
Each soul blooms with its own sacred truth,
Each heart beats to rhythms of its own youth.

Your prayers may rise on words I've never known,
Your skin may tell stories different from my own.
Your traditions may follow paths I cannot see,
Yet worthy of honor they will always be.

For what binds us together runs deeper than blood—
The shared human yearning to be understood.
In our differences lies beauty, in diversity strength,
A tapestry of souls stretching infinite length.

So I stand beside you, not despite who you are,
But because your light shines like a different star.
In the constellation of humanity we each hold space,
United in dignity, respect, and grace.

# Common Ground

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For we are all gardens grown from different seed.
His prayers may rise on words I do not know,
His skin may catch the light with a different glow.

The temples of his heart may not match mine,
Yet dignity and worth in each design.
The paths we walk may wander far apart,
But human hopes beat in each human heart.

What matters not is how we name the stars,
But that we see their beauty from afar.
Not how we kneel, or stand, or bow in prayer,
But that we seek to find some meaning there.

So let us meet as equals on this earth,
Each valued for our spirit and our worth.
For wisdom lies in open hands, not fists—
In understanding how the other exists.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
Wake, Work, Home, Eat, Sleep

The rhythm of existence, five simple beats,
A metronome of days that still repeats.
Wake to alarms and morning's gentle light,
Shed dreams like leaves and face the coming fight.

Work consumes the hours, minutes sold for pay,
Emails, meetings, deadlines mark the way.
Hands and mind in service, trading time for bread,
Following the paths that countless feet have tread.

Home becomes a haven as the day grows old,
Sanctuary where true stories can be told.
Keys in lock, shoes off, shoulders finally ease,
The mask of day removed with gentle release.

Eat to fuel the body, gather at the table,
Nourishment and comfort, as much as we are able.
In food we find connection, memories, and care,
Simple sustenance becomes communion there.

Sleep descends like mercy, consciousness unbound,
In darkness and in silence, healing can be found.
The cycle ends to start again with morning's call,
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—the dance of us all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

responses.text:
Let the Night Sleep

Hush now, restless thoughts that spin and weave,
Let the night sleep in her velvet gown.
The moon has cast her silver spell, believe
That darkness too deserves its silent crown.

Stars blink slowly in their distant beds,
While shadows dance in corners, soft and deep.
The world has bowed its weary, troubled head—
Let the night sleep, let the night sleep.

Dreams unfold in chambers dark and still,
As time suspends between each gentle breath.
The owl's wisdom echoes from the hill:
In darkness lies not fear, but quiet depth.

So close your eyes and loose your grip on day,
Let worries into midnight waters seep.
The dawn will come in its own measured way—
For now, just let the night sleep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

UNSETTLED HOPE

We build our walls of certainty,
Arrange our lives in perfect rows,
Seek comfort in security,
As if that's all a life should know.

But listen to the restless wind
That whispers truths we dare not face:
The settled soul has never sinned,
Nor stumbled into saving grace.

For in the chaos of the fall,
In questions that disturb our sleep,
In doubts that scale our fortress wall,
Lies wisdom infinitely deep.

The unsettled heart beats wildest,
Creates what comfort never could.
The searching mind climbs highest,
Finds paths through darkest wood.

So bless the ground that shifts beneath,
The plans that crumble into dust.
In unsettled soil, hope finds breath,
In change, we learn to truly trust.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Because another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flowery meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart be torn asunder
By the weight of ceaseless wonder?
Shall I chase what cannot last,
Mourning present, future, past?
Let the stars burn out above,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's delight, my soul's most precious bloom,
Whose laughter filled the chambers of my days
And cast its light through even darkest gloom.

The years we shared, too fleeting in their course,
Have left their mark upon my weathered face.
I trace your shadow in the morning light,
And feel your absence in each empty space.

How strange it seems that you should journey on
While I remain to watch the seasons turn.
The world still spins, indifferent to my loss,
While memories like distant candles burn.

Go forth, beloved, into realms unknown,
Take with you all the love I've ever shown.
Though parting cleaves my spirit like a sword,
In some far dawn, perhaps, we'll meet once more.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now beyond my reach.
Time's cruel tide has swept you far away,
Like morning mist that fades with breaking day.

I held you once, so small within my palm,

And now I stand alone in silent night.

What father would not give his final breath

The natural order I cannot rearrange.

So go, beloved, seek your destined path,
Carry my love as armor for your soul.
Though distance grows between our separate ways,
In spirit's realm, my child, with you I'll stay.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
Abandoned Tears

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like everything else,
Rolling down cheeks that have known too much sorrow,
Disappearing into the void of forgotten pain.

Each droplet—a traitor to my grief,
Evaporating before witnesses can see
The depth of wounds I carry silently.
Even my sadness refuses to remain.

The evidence of heartbreak vanishes,
Leaving me hollow, with nothing to prove
That I felt anything at all.
My suffering becomes invisible,

Like whispers in a hurricane,
Like footprints in rushing water.
I am left alone with empty eyes,
Betrayed even by my own tears.

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,

Even my sorrow refuses to remain,

These droplets of grief—my silent pain—
Disappear before their journey's done.

If sadness won't linger in liquid form,
Perhaps it's carved deeper than what eyes can see.

While my cheeks stay dry, betraying me.

I reach for the wetness to prove I still feel,
But my companions of grief have taken flight.
Even in anguish, I cannot reveal
The depth of darkness in my endless night.

Afraid of what might be.

What scars have taught you caution?

The dawn your timid song,

Has waited far too long.

O forlorn heart, so pure and true,
Take one small step, and then
Discover that in letting go,
You'll truly live again.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

responses.text:
Hollow Spaces

How can you grieve and express loss?
When words fall short like autumn leaves,
And memories blur like morning frost.

I carry your absence like river stones,
Smooth from handling, heavy in pockets,
A weight that anchors me to earth.

Some days I speak to empty rooms,
Hoping echoes might return your voice.
Some nights I leave your chair unfilled.

Grief lives in rituals—the cup of tea
I still prepare but never serve,
The door I open before remembering.

Perhaps we grieve in silent gestures:
In pressed flowers between book pages,
In paths unworn, in songs unsung.

The world continues its relentless spin
While I stand still in your departure,
Learning to breathe around this hollow space.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

responses.text:
In the Hollow of Loss

How can you grieve and express loss?
When words fall short like autumn leaves,
And silence weighs a mountain's cost
Upon the chest that barely breathes.

Perhaps in tears that streak the face,
Or in the space between each word,
In rituals we now embrace,
Or memories no longer blurred.

Some find it in the songs they play,
Or letters written, never sent.
Others in the light of day,
Or darkness where they can lament.

Grief flows like rivers to the sea,
Different paths, the same release.
It asks not how, but simply to be
Acknowledged, honored, found in peace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

responses.text:
The Weight of Absence

How can you grieve and express loss?
When words falter at the edge of pain,
When memories float like autumn leaves
Across the surface of your days.

Perhaps in silence, in the space
Between heartbeats, in empty rooms
Where echoes linger of a voice
That once filled corners with its warmth.

Perhaps in tears that come unbidden,
In sudden waves that crash and break
Against the shoreline of your soul,
Reshaping what you thought was solid ground.

Or in the rituals we create:
A candle lit, a photo touched,
A journey to a cherished place
Where shadows hold what time has claimed.

The body knows what minds cannot express—
In shoulders curved against the weight,
In hands that reach for what's not there,
In breath that catches, unexpectedly.

Grief speaks in languages beyond our words,
A testament to love that doesn't end
When presence turns to memory.
It simply learns to speak your name in different ways.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'They were indeed simple people'

responses.text:
They Were Indeed Simple People

They were indeed simple people,
With hands weathered by honest toil,
Their wealth measured not in gold coins
But in the richness of their soil.

Their homes lacked ornate trappings,
No chandeliers or marble floors,
Yet warmth flowed through their humble rooms
When neighbors knocked upon their doors.

They spoke in plain and truthful words,
No need for clever, sharp disguise,
The wisdom in their quiet ways
Reflected in their patient eyes.

They were indeed simple people,
Who found their joy in daily bread,
In stories shared by firelight,
And in the stars that graced their head.

Their legacy not carved in stone,
Nor written down in history's tome,
But in the kindness that they showed
And seeds of goodness they had sown.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'IT is the dead of night:'

responses.text:
IT is the dead of night:
When shadows claim their throne,
And silence reigns with gentle might,
As darkness stands alone.

The moon, a silver sentinel,
Casts ghostly light below,
While stars their ancient stories tell
In whispered, twinkling glow.

The world now holds its breath in sleep,
As dreams take flight and soar,
While secrets that the daylight keeps
Find voice on midnight's shore.

In this still hour between the days,
When time seems frozen still,
The universe in wonder stays,
Suspended at night's will.

responses.text:
Beneath the Ashes

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
Hidden beneath the dust of daily toil,
A spirit unbroken by cruel words spoken,
A heart that remains pure despite the soil.

In hope that shines like a gleaming sword.

In dreams sustained through darkest nights,
In courage no hardship can taint.

The magic lies not in midnight charms,
But in the soul that rises each dawn,
Carrying grace through bitter storms,
Until its radiant truth is drawn.

For Cinderella is not just a tale of fate,
But the triumph of what lies within—
The splendor waiting to illuminate
Once we let our real selves begin.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

responses.text:
ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Adieu, O soldier! Your march is done,
Your boots now rest where battles won
Cast shadows long across the field,
Where courage bloomed and would not yield.

The bugle's cry fades in the air,
As twilight claims your vacant chair.
Your medals shine with stories told
Of honor kept and actions bold.

Adieu, O soldier! Time moves on,
Your legacy in hearts lives drawn.
The flag you served now drapes in grace,
A nation's thanks for your embrace.

In silence now, we stand and know
The debt of freedom that we owe.
Adieu, O soldier! Rest complete,
Your sacrifice made bitter sweet.

The bar around us cheered for other victories,
For games that mattered to the crowds below.

I took her hand and led her to the door,
"Let's make our own game now," I dared to say.

No whistles, crowds, or painted boundary lines.
Just us—our heartbeats keeping perfect time,
The only score that truly mattered: mine and thine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,'

responses.text:
Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
Some in their wealth, some in their body's might,
Some in their garments, though new-fangled ill,
Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;

And every humour hath its adjunct pleasure,
Wherein it finds a joy above the rest:
But these particulars are not my measure;
All these I better in one general best.

Thy love is better than high birth to me,
Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,
Of more delight than hawks or horses be;
And having thee, of all men's pride I boast—

This only lives in thee, in whom alone
I find the strength that makes all glories known.

Some in their garments, though new-fangled ill,
Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;
And every humor hath his adjunct pleasure,
Wherein it finds a joy above the rest.

But these particulars are not my measure;
All these I better in one general best.
Thy love is better than high birth to me,
Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,
Of more delight than hawks or horses be;
And having thee, of all men's pride I boast—

This only brings me joy that cannot fade:
That in thy heart, my heart has made its trade.

To reach you was my journey's end, worth every slip and fall.

And now beside you, finally, my weary heart finds rest,
The river's wisdom vindicated, its painful path was best.
For what is earned through struggle holds a beauty all its own,
And love that's found through hardship is the strongest ever known.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,'

responses.text:
The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through rapids fierce and valleys deep where shadows played their song.
I followed rushing waters as they carved through ancient stone,
Trusting in their wisdom as I journeyed on alone.

The current pulled me forward when my strength had nearly fled,
When doubt crept in like morning mist and filled my heart with dread.
Each bend revealed new challenges, each day a different shore,
Yet something in the water's voice kept urging, "Journey more."

Through seasons changing overhead and landscapes wild and strange,
The river was my constant as all else would shift and change.
It whispered of a promise, of a place I'd someday find,
Where weary souls find harbor and where broken hearts unbind.

And when at last I found you at the river's gentle end,
Where waters calm and deepen as they reach the ocean's bend,
I understood the journey, every struggle, every mile—
The river led me to you, and in you, I found my smile.
